metadata.title: Piaggio P.180 Avanti
aws::graph::propositions: # Piaggio P.180 Avanti Development and Design Features
Learjet's design influence can be seen in the steeply raked windshield of the Piaggio P.180 Avanti.
Learjet's design influence can be seen in the two large ventral delta fins under the tail of the Piaggio P.180 Avanti.
The ventral delta fins provide a nose-down pitching moment at high angles of attack.
The ventral delta fins help to avoid a potential stall at high angles of attack.
The ventral delta fins increase stability in flight by damping yaw.
The ventral delta fins increase stability in flight by damping Dutch roll.
Gates Learjet's financial problems ended their collaboration with Piaggio in January 1986.
Piaggio continued the P.180 Avanti project after Gates Learjet's departure.
The first prototype of the Piaggio P.180 Avanti flew on 23 September 1986.
The Piaggio P.180 Avanti received Italian certification on 7 March 1990.
The Piaggio P.180 Avanti obtained American certification on 2 October 1990.
The first 12 fuselages of the Piaggio P.180 Avanti were manufactured in Wichita, Kansas.
H & H Parts manufactured some of the first 12 fuselages of the Piaggio P.180 Avanti.
Plessey Midwest manufactured some of the first 12 fuselages of the Piaggio P.180 Avanti.
The fuselages manufactured in Wichita were flown to Italy for final assembly.
Avanti Aviation Wichita ran out of money in 1994.
The Piaggio P.180 Avanti project languished after Avanti Aviation Wichita ran out of money.
A group of investors became involved in the Piaggio P.180 Avanti project in 1998.
Piero Ferrari led the group of investors that became involved in the Piaggio P.180 Avanti project in 1998.

text:
Learjet's design influence can be seen in the steeply raked windshield and the two large ventral delta fins under the tail. At high angles of attack these delta fins provide a nose-down pitching moment and help to avoid a potential stall, and they increase stability in flight by damping yaw and Dutch roll.
Gates Learjet's financial problems ended their collaboration in January 1986, but Piaggio continued the project, and the first prototype flew on 23 September 1986. The P.180 Avanti received Italian certification on 7 March 1990 and American certification was obtained on 2 October 1990.
The first 12 fuselages were manufactured in Wichita, Kansas, with H & H Parts and Plessey Midwest, then flown to Italy for final assembly. Avanti Aviation Wichita ran out of money in 1994; the project languished until a group of investors led by Piero Ferrari became involved in 1998.
